titleStmt.title: Molecular phylogeny and community fingerprinting of coral-associated Symbiodinium north of the Arabian Gulf

affiliation.orgName: Public Authority of Applied Education and Training

analytic.title: Molecular phylogeny and community fingerprinting of coral-associated Symbiodinium north of the Arabian Gulf

biblStruct.note: Received 18 January 2015 Received in revised form 17 April 2016 Accepted 25 April 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Symbiodinium North Arabian Gulf corals Temporal variation Spatial variation RFLP DGGE Marine Pollution Bulletin 108 (2016) 94-104

abstract.p: Understanding coral-Symbiodinium relationships including changes in the genotypes and the numbers of Symbiodinium can explain the ability of Kuwait coral to survive high fluctuations in water temperature. In the current study, the diversity of Symbiodinium associated with fourteen coral species from six reef systems south of Kuwait was investigated. The results proved the predominance of clade C members in all corals tested, which reflects the importance of this type in helping corals thrive in the Gulf's harsh conditions. Platygyra daedalea was the only coral found that harbored clades A, B and C in their tissue but it is the most vulnerable coral for bleaching. The total number of Symbiodinium-like cells in the seawater was 10 cell ml −1 while in coral tissue and mucus 10 7 cell g −1 and 10 7 cell ml −1 were found, respectively, and a strong positive correlation with the seawater temperature, salinity and conductivity was found.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Coral reefs are usually surrounded by oligotrophic, nutrient poor, water systems where productivity rarely exceeds 0.01 g of fixed carbon m −2 day −1 (Hatcher, 1988). However, productivity within coral tissue can reach 40 g of fixed carbon m −2 day − 1 (Hatcher, 1988;Hoegh-Guldberg, 1999). This makes coral reefs one of the most productive systems on Earth, due to the unique relationship between the corals and their algal symbionts, commonly known as zooxanthellae, which are responsible for 50-70% of the total primary production in most reefs (D'Angelo and Wiedenmann, 2014). The zooxanthellae are unicellular dinoflagellates from the genus Symbiodinium (Rowan and Powers, 1991a;Baker, 1999;Carlos et al., 1999;Goulet, 2006) and provide the coral host with up to 95% of their own metabolites such as glycerol, glucose, alanine and organic acids necessary for coral productivity and growth Powers, 1991a, 1991b;Pochon et al., 2004). In return, the coral provides the Symbiodinium with urea, amino acids, glycerophosphate and CO 2 needed by the algae for photosynthesis (Hackett et al., 2004). Furthermore, the hard coral structure provides the endosymbionts with protection against grazing and sedimentation, while the mucus production and sloughing process carried by the coral themselves prevent sediments from accumulating on the coral surface, hence hindering light from reaching the endosymbionts (Rogers, 1990). Historically, the symbiotic dinoflagellates in corals probably evolved from nonsymbiotic dinoflagellates (Rowan, 1998). The symbiotic relationship starts when the newly formed coral colony acquires the photosynthetic symbiont from the surrounding environment or from the eggs, depending entirely on the reproduction mode of each coral species (Thornhill et al., 2006).

Recent studies have shown that five genetic clades of Symbiodinium are associated with corals: A, B, C, D and G (Stat et al., 2008). Baker and Romanski (2007) reported that more than 50% of scleractinian corals (250 species) can host more than one Symbiodinium clade and that diverse symbionts can be found within the same clade; this is contrary to the conclusion of Goulet (2006) who suggested that 77% of the 442 scleractinian and octocorals species host a single Symbiodinium clade and only 23% host multiple clades. The findings of Baker and Romanski (2007) are widely accepted, and it is believed that the corals harboring multiple clades can change the symbiont type according to the prevailing conditions. Different environmental factors both regulate the distribution and determine the type of Symbiodinium clades inhabiting the coral tissue (Van Oppen et al., 2001;Goulet and Coffroth, 2003). Therefore, sclerectinian corals can flexibly associate with assorted symbionts with diverse physiologies which can confer better resistance to extreme environmental conditions (Baker, 2003;Baker et al., 2004;Berkelmans and Van Oppen, 2006).

In this context, Rowan and Knowlton (1995) reported that in the same Montastraea annularis individual, variation in the distribution of Symbiodinium was linked primarily to light exposure. The tissue exposed to high light intensity harbored clade A and B, while coral tissue exposed to lower light intensity harbored clade C. Symbiodinium clade D has been linked to temperature conditions and is known to be thermotolerant (Toller et al., 2001;Rowan, 2004) with the ability to tolerate a water temperature variation from 14 to 34°C (Mostafavi et al., 2007). Mostafavi et al. (2007) also reported that clade D was predominant in Acropora clathrata, Cyphastrea microphthalma, Favia pallida, Tubinaria reniformis, Pavona decussata, Platygyra daedalea, and Psammocora contigua, sampled from the coasts of Iran, north of the Arabian Gulf, while clade C was found only in Porites compressa and P. contigua.

It is well documented that the Arabian Gulf is one of the hottest water bodies on Earth (Riegl and Purkis, 2012;Hume et al., 2015;Bento et al., 2016). Coral reefs found in the Arabian Gulf are regularly exposed to large variations in water temperature, ranging from 11°C to 37°C (Coles and Riegl, 2012). There have been some key research results concerning adaptation strategies associated with coral reefs in the warm waters of the Arabian Gulf (see Riegl and Purkis, 2012). Coral studies from Saudi Arabia (Baker et al., 2004), Iran (Mostafavi et al., 2007;Shahhosseiny et al., 2011) and Abu Dhabi (Hume et al., 2013) suggest that Symbiodinium clades A, C and D are present in the Gulf corals. While Baker et al. (2004), Mostafavi et al. (2007) and Shahhosseiny et al. (2011) showed the predominance of the thermotolerant clade D in the corals they investigated, Hume et al. (2013) showed the predominance of clade C3 in 7 thermotolerant reef builders in Abu Dhabi corals. Hume et al. (2013) suggested that clade D may be partially responsible for the resilience of the Gulf corals. Recently, Symbiodinium thermophilum clade C3 was identified as the most prevalent clade found in Abu Dhabi corals (Hume et al., 2015).

So far, all of the studies done on the Gulf coral Symbiodinium were conducted either south of the Gulf or north of the Gulf near the coast of Iran; there are no regional-based studies on the Kuwaiti Reefs, the most northern coral reefs in the Arabian Gulf. No information is available about the type of Symbiodinium that is present in these coral reefs, which regularly experience temperatures above 30°C. Coral reefs are found south of Kuwait across an inshore to offshore gradient. Inshore coral reefs are relatively small in size and occur in shallow waters of depths between 3 and 8 m, while offshore coral reefs can be found at depths reaching 30 m. Corals in Kuwait reefs are exposed to unique conditions; they experience one of the highest annual temperature variations with temperatures of more than 36°C in the summer (Al-Yamani et al., 2004) and low temperatures of 9°C in the winter (Spalding et al., 2001). Studies performed on corals from other parts of the world have shown that no other coral system on Earth could survive the prolonged high temperatures that the Kuwaiti and the Gulf corals experience regularly. Reports showed that the Great Barrier Reef corals bleached when water temperature exceeded a 10 day threshold of 30.8°C (Berkelmans et al., 2004), while Caribbean corals (for example, Montastrea annulari) bleached when the temperature exceeded 32°C (Fitt and Warner, 1995). Therefore, understanding the coral-Symbiodinium relationship may be useful to further clarify how Kuwait corals can adapt to the high variation in water temperature. The current study provides information about Symbiodinium diversity and abundance in Kuwait corals, and the results show both the predominance of clade C in 14 coral species sampled from inshore and offshore reef systems south of Kuwait and spatial and temporal variation in the Symbiodinium population.

div.head: Sampling sites and sample collection
div.p: Samples were collected from three offshore and three inshore reef systems (Fig. 1) on April, May, July and October 2008. The samples were utilized to investigate spatial and temporal variation in Symbiodinium diversity and abundance. All reef systems investigated were located south of Kuwait, and in total, 14 different coral species were investigated (Table 1). Three different coral colonies of each coral species were sampled in triplicate from various parts of the colony. From each coral colony one-centimeter size coral nubbins were collected underwater in sterile plastic bags and coral mucus was harvested in the field using sterile 20 ml sterile syringes (Cervino et al., 2008). Seawater samples from 1 m away from the sampled coral colonies were collected in 1 l sterile polyethylene bottles to investigate the free-living Symbiodinium. All samples were packed on ice and returned to the laboratory for immediate processing. At all sites, water temperature, pH, salinity, turbidity and conductivity were measured using a Multi-Parameter Water Quality Checker (Horiba, USA) ( Table S1, Supplementary data).

div.head: Sample processing
div.p: The seawater samples were filtered through a 0.45 μm membrane filter (Whatman, England). The filter was cut with a sterile blade, and the pieces were transferred to sterile 15 ml tubes containing 2 ml of sterile phosphate buffer saline (PBS; 8 g NaCl, 0.2 g KCl, 1.44 g Na 2 HPO 4 , 0.24 g KH 2 PO 4 in 1 l of water, pH adjusted to 7.4, Sambrook et al., 1989) before storing at −20°C for molecular analysis. In addition, 10 ml aliquots of fresh water samples were fixed in 2% v/v formaldehyde and stored at 4°C for a period of 1 day to 1 week before being examined under an epifluorescent microscope in order to determine the abundance of the Symbiodinium-like cells (Mahmoud et al., 2005). Each coral nubbin was washed in a sterile bag with 10 ml of sterile 3% NaCl water and vigorously shaken for 5 min to release the epiphytic zooxanthellae. The nubbins were then weighed and turned into a slurry using a sterile mortar and pestle (Thurber et al., 2009). Five milliliters of the coral slurry, now treated as a tissue sample throughout the study, was fixed with 2% v/v formaldehyde and used for a direct count. An additional 5 ml of the suspension was pipetted into 5 sterile Eppendorf tubes containing 0.5 ml aliquots of sterile PBS and stored at −20°C for molecular analysis (Al-Sarraf, 2009).

Mucus samples were carefully injected into 15 ml sterile tubes and separated from the water by centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 5 min. The mucus volume was estimated, and 10 ml of sterile 3% NaCl water was added to the mucus followed by vigorous shaking to form a homogeneous suspension. Each 1 ml of the suspension was transferred into 8 Eppendorf tubes containing 0.5 ml PBS and stored at −20°C for later use in molecular analysis. Another 1 ml of the suspension was transferred to 2 Eppendorf tubes containing 2% v/v formaldehyde and examined under the epiflourescent microscope (Zeiss, Germany) (Al-Sarraf, 2009).

div.head: Direct counting of Symbiodinium-like cells using an epifluorescent microscope
div.p: One milliliter of formaldehyde fixed samples was filtered on 0.22 μm nitrocellulose membrane filters (Millipore, Ireland). The membrane filters were examined under a Zeiss Epiflourescent Microscope (Zeiss, Germany) equipped with a green excitation filter (510-560 nm) and barrier filter LP 590. Cells with the expected size and shape were counted in 20 fields. Then, the total number of cells in the sample was determined.

div.head: DNA extraction and polymerase chain reaction
div.p: DNA from the coral tissue and mucus was extracted using Soil Spin Kit (Qbiogene, USA). The extraction procedure was done following the manufacturer's protocol. Modified versions of the protocols of Schafer and Muyzer (2001) and Baker (1999) were followed to extract the DNA from the seawater samples.

Different target sites were amplified using different primers (Table S2, Supplementary data) Powers, 1991a, 1991b;Baker, 1999;Pochon et al., 2001;Mostafavi et al., 2007). The purpose was to investigate different nuclear regions in order to obtain the genetic information from different sites to detect the variation in Symbiodinium diversity in the samples. The PCR program for each primer is provided in Table S3 in the supplementary data (Baker, 1999;Pochon et al., 2001;Goulet and Coffroth, 2003;Mostafavi et al., 2007). Each PCR reaction was conducted using a PCR-Ready-To-Go Kit (GE health care, UK). To each reaction tube, 25 ng of the extracted DNA and 30 pmol of each primer set, both forward and reverse primers, were added, and a final volume of 25 μl was obtained by adding molecular water. The amplification process was carried out using a GeneAmp PCR system 9700 Thermocycler (Applied Biosystem, USA).

div.head: Restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLP)
div.p: The variations in the Symbiodinium clades were tested by digesting the DNA amplified with different primers with Taq I (Promega, USA) and HindIII (Promega, USA) restriction enzymes. The digestion reactions were conducted in triplicate. Five microliters of the DNA was digested using a restriction enzymes kit following the manufacturer's protocol. The tubes were incubated in a water bath at 37°C for 6 h for Taq I and overnight for HindIII.

The digested DNA samples were visualized on 1.5% agarose gel with a 100 bp low-ladder (Invitrogen, USA). The resulting bands were compared with standards of different Symbiodinium clades obtained from Symbiodinium culture collections in Scott Santos' laboratory (Auburn University, USA) Marine and Atmospheric Research in Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO; Tasmani, Australia; Table S4, Supplementary data).

div.head: Denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE)
div.p: Denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis was used to differentiate between Symbiodinium sp. in environmental samples. The ITS region was used to show high resolution below the species level (LaJeunesse, 2001). The samples were amplified with ITS_DINO described in Table S2, Supplementary data and ITS2CLAMP specific primers (5′-CGCCCG CCGCGCCCCGCGCCCGTCCCGCCGCCCCCGCCCGGGATCCATATGCTTAA GTTCAGCGGGT-3′) with the "touchdown" PCR program (LaJeunesse and Trench, 2000). The PCR program began with the initial denaturation at 94°C for 5 min followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 94°C for 30 s, extension at 72°C for 30 s, and the touchdown annealing step in which the temperature started at 62°C and decreased one degree every two cycles for 20 cycles. Then the annealing temperature was fixed at 52°C for another 15 cycles. The final extension step was at 72°C for 7 min. The D-code Universal Mutation Detection (BioRad Protean II) System (BioRad, USA) was used to run the DGGE. Two 6% polyacrylamide DGGE gels with denaturant gradients of 40% and 60% were used. The gels were run at 45 V at 60°C for 16 h. Finally, the gel was stained with ethidium bromide for 30 min before visualization under a UV transilluminator (UVP, UK).

div.head: Gene cloning and sequencing
div.p: Genomic DNA from all the samples collected at the various sampling dates was pooled and used for PCR. Eight microliters of the PCR product resulting from the Rowan and Powers (1991a) and Baker (1999) primers were added to 2 μl of an A-Addition kit (QIAGEN, Germany) and gently mixed. The mixture was incubated in a water bath at 37°C for 30 min. The treated DNA was inserted into a pGEM-T Easy Vector System I (Promega, USA) following the manufacturer's protocol. Five microliters of the treated sample was transferred to a tube containing 100 μl of Escherichia coli DH5α competent cells. The rest of the cloning steps were conducting following the protocols in Sambrook et al. (1989).

Plasmids were extracted from E. coli DH5α using a QIAprep Miniprep Plasmid DNA Extraction kit (QIAGEN, USA). The inserted PCR products were amplified using the primer set 18F1 (5′-AGCTCG TAGTTGGATTTCTG-3′) and 18R1 (5′-AGTCAAATTAAGCCGCAGGC-3′) (Toller et al., 2001). The PCR program began with an initial denaturation step at 94°C for 5 min, followed by 30 cycles in which the denaturation temperature was set at 94°C for 30 s, annealing at 50°C for 45 s and extension at 72°C for 30 s. The final extension step was at 72°C for 7 min. The inserted PCR products were also amplified with ss3Z and ss5 primers as described in Table S2.

The amplified DNA from the cloned cells was purified using a QIAquick PCR purification kit (QIAGEN, USA) following the manufacturer's protocol. The purified PCR product was fluorescently labeled using a Big Dye terminator (V 3.1) reagent mix (Applied Biosystem, USA). The samples were sequenced using a 3130xl genetic analyzer (ABI, USA), and sequences were analyzed by BLAST to identify their nearest neighbor in the GenBank. The sequences were aligned to the reference sequences obtained from the GenBank using Clustal X (Thompson et al., 1997). Phylogenetic trees were constructed using neighbor-joining including bootstrap analysis with PAUP*V.4 and were based on 2000 replicates (Swofford, 1998).

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: Within-site and within-host variations in the Symbiodinium-like cell abundance were detected using a t-test, while between-host, between-site and temporal variation in Symbiodinium-like cell abundance was investigated using a one-way ANOVA test. Principle component analysis (PCA) was used to examine the relationships between the environmental variables, i.e., seawater quality parameters and the Symbiodinium-like cell abundance in the coral tissue, mucus and seawater samples.

div.head: Phylogenetic diversity of Symbiodinium from Kuwait corals investigated using a clone library
div.p: The phylogenetic diversity of the Symbiodinium associated with the tissue of various coral hosts sampled between April and October 2008 from 3 offshore and 3 inshore reef systems (Table 1) was assessed using a cloning-sequencing technique. Pooling the genomic materials of all coral samples produced a clone library composed of 300 clones that revealed upon sequencing a low diversity of Symbiodinium. Clade C predominated in the clone library, with 95% of the clones were within group and only 5% of the clones were affiliated with Symbiodinium clade A. The phylogenetic analysis for the clones that matched clade C members suggested that they might belong to diverse symbionts within the same clade (Fig. 2).

div.head: Symbiodinium community composition in 13 different coral hosts
div.p: The abundance and diversity of the Symbiodinium associated with 13 different coral hosts from two inshore and three offshore sites sampled during the summer (June-July 2008) south of Kuwait (Table 1) were assessed. The results showed different hosts harbored different numbers of symbionts, but the readings obtained from each coral species cannot be compared with other species because the Symbiodinium abundance was determined in a slurry made of coral tissue and skeletons. The variation in the tissue to skeleton ratio for each species causes difficulty in comparing various coral genera. However, the results do indicate the abundance of Symbiodinium-like cells in each coral investigated. C. microphthalma was found to harbor a high number of Symbiodinium-like cells in its tissue (i.e., 26.4 × 10 cell g − 1 ) and mucus (i.e., 36.8 × 10 cell ml −1 ) (Fig. 3). Coscinaraea columna was found to harbor a low number of Symbiodinium-like cells in their tissue (i.e., 8.14 × 10 cell g −1 ), while P. decussata harbored a low number of Symbiodinium-like cells in their mucus (i.e., 15.2 × 10 cell ml − 1 ). Significantly higher numbers (t = 4.30, P b 0.001) of Symbiodinium-like cells were found in the coral mucus than in the coral tissue in all thirteen coral species.

An RFLP and DGGE analysis (Figs. S1 and S2, Supplementary data) showed clade C predominated in the tissue and mucus of all corals sampled from coral reef sites across the inshore to offshore gradient Fig. 2. Neighbor-joining tree shows partial 18S rDNA sequence of Symbiodinium sp. clones found associated with coral tissue and their nearest match from the GenBank. Sequences from the current study are indicated in boldface. The percentage of 2000 bootstrap replicate is shown below the nodes. Fig. 3. The total number of Symbiodinium-like cells in 13 coral hosts tissue and mucus sampled from two inshore and three offshore reef systems on June-July 2008. (Table 2). P. daedalea was the only exception, in which the tissue of the coral sampled from Umm Al-Maradim harbored Symbiodinium clades C and B together (Table 2).

An investigation of the free-living Symbiodinium abundance in the seawater collected from the five sites studied during the summer (Table 1) showed different numbers of Symbiodinium (Fig. 4). The lowest numbers were recorded in Kubbar water samples (average = 18.44 × 10 7 cell ml − 1 ), and the highest were found in Umm Al-Maradim water samples (average = 27.1 × 10 7 cell m −1 ), but despite the variation in the numbers detected, the results were not significantly different.
3.3. Temporal variations in the Symbiodinium community composition of four coral species inhabiting the inshore reef system of Qit'at Benaya

Significant differences (P b 0.001) in the numbers of Symbiodiniumlike cells were recorded in the tissue and mucus of four coral species (Porites horrisoni, P. decussata, C. microphthalma and P. daedalea) sampled in the spring (May) and summer (July). All four coral species sampled at the inshore reef system of Qit'at Benaya showed high symbiont numbers in the tissue and mucus during the summer in comparison to spring (Fig. 5A and B). The correlation between the numbers of Symbiodinium-like cells measured in the coral mucus and tissue was tested using a Pearson correlation test. The results showed the presence of a significant positive correlation (r = 0.358, P b 0.02) between Symbiodinium-like cells in coral tissue and mucus, suggesting that an increase in the symbiont numbers in the coral tissue is accompanied by an increase in the coral mucus.

A molecular investigation of the Symbiodinium diversity showed that all corals investigated harbored clade C in their tissue and mucus samples at both sampling times. P. daedalea tissue sampled in spring was an exception in which both clades B and C were detected (Table 2).

3.4. Spatial and temporal variation in Symbiodinium community composition associated with P. daedalea P. daedalea was the only coral in the study found to harbor more than one Symbiodinium clades in the tissue; therefore it was chosen for further investigation of the spatial and temporal variation in the Symbiodinium community.

Common in both inshore and offshore reef systems of Kuwait, P. daedalea was a perfect candidate to study the spatial variation in the Symbiodinium community. P. daedalea was sampled during spring from the inshore reef system of Qit'at Benaya and the offshore reef system of Umm Al-Maradim as the two sites are close to each other with only 28.7 km distance between them and thus sampled within the same day. Significantly higher numbers of Symbiodinium-like cells (P b 0.00) were found in P. daedalea tissue and mucus sampled from the offshore site than in samples collected from the inshore reef system (Fig. 6). However, no significant differences (P N 0.05) were recorded in the number of free-living Symbiodinium-like cells in the seawater at both sites.

The identity of the Symbiodinium clades associated with P. daedalea from the two sites was investigated using RFLP and DGGE, showing the dominance of clades A, B and C in the tissue samples collected from the offshore reef system, while the inshore reef samples were dominated by Symbiodinium clades B and C ( Table 2). The coral mucus from P. daedalea at both reefs contained only Symbiodinium clade C (Table 2). Free-living Symbiodinium clades A, B and C were detected in the seawater samples collected at both sites in addition to clade E, which was detected only in the seawater collected from the inshore reef system at Qit'at Benaya.

The temporal variation in the Symbiodinium community composition of P. daedalea sampled from Umm Al-Maradim offshore reef system was compared for spring, summer and autumn. There were significant differences (P b 0.01) in the total number of Symbiodinium-like cells associated with the coral tissue over the three seasons. The highest numbers of Symbiodinium were recorded in P. daedalea tissue sampled during summer, and the lowest numbers were in the spring samples (Fig. 7). The same situation was found for free-living Symbiodinium in seawater (Fig. 4).

The PCA results for the correlation between the seawater quality parameters from all sites, and the number of Symbiodinium-like cells associated with the coral tissue and mucus as well as free-living Symbiodinium-like cells from all sites showed that the first principal component increased with increasing conductivity, temperature, salinity, and the number of Symbiodinium-like cells in the coral tissue, mucus

div.p: and water, suggesting that these five criteria varied together; i.e., if one of the water parameters increased, the number of Symbiodinium-like cells also increased (Fig. 8).

The molecular investigation provided evidence for Symbiodinium clades A, B and C predominating in P. daedalea tissue during spring, while clades B and C and clades A and C, respectively, predominated in the summer and autumn samples (Table 2). An analysis of the P. daedalea mucus showed the occurrence of clade C members alone (Table 2), while clades A, B and C were present in the water samples in all three seasons. Clade D was detected in the water samples collected in the summer only in a free-living form.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The uniqueness of the Kuwait corals stems from their ability to tolerate high variations in water temperature during different seasons. Understanding coral-Symbiodinium relationships will be useful to further clarify how Kuwait corals adapt to such variations for which changes in the genotype and the numbers of Symbiodinium can explain the ability of the coral to adapt to various environmental stresses (Berkelmans and Van Oppen, 2006).

div.head: Abundance of coral-associated Symbiodinium north of the Arabian Gulf
div.p: This study recorded significantly higher Symbiodinium-like cell numbers in P. daedalea coral tissue and mucus sampled during summer compared with spring and autumn. These findings are contrary to the findings of Drohan et al. (2005) who reported a reduction in the Symbiodinium-like cell density after increases in both temperature and light intensity, which damaged photosystem II in the symbionts. However, the high recorded numbers might be explained by a decrease in the symbiont densities at the end of the high temperature season and not during the season (Douglas, 2003) as the samples were collected during July and not at the end of August. The increase in the density of Symbiodinium recorded in the summer is likely to be related to an increase in the inorganic nitrogen level (i.e., nitrate and nitrite) in Kuwait seawater (Sakami, 2000) typically recorded during the summer months (Al-Yamani et al., 2004;Devlin et al., 2015;Lyons et al., 2015). Moreover, P. daedalea coral tissue and mucus sampled from the Umm Al-Maradim offshore reef system in April 2008 was found to harbor significantly higher numbers of Symbiodinium than samples from the Qit'at Benaya inshore reef system. Greater thermal stability in offshore systems than in inshore systems (Venn et al., 2008) and higher allochthonous input of nutrients and pollutants affecting the Kuwait inshore systems explain such spatial variation in Symbiodinium abundance.

Throughout the study, the Symbiodinium numbers in coral mucus were always significantly higher than in coral tissue. This could be attributed to the nature of the coral mucus, which is rich in polysaccharide materials that help to recruit cells from the surrounding environment, both the water column and benthos, providing them with nutrients and protection (Coffroth et al., 2006). Additionally, the mucus receives Symbiodinium that are repelled by the coral tissue in which they have a significant role in providing mucus-associated microbes with the oxygen necessary for respiration and with glycerides and wax esters necessary for metabolism. This latter suggestion is supported by the findings of Baghdasarian and Muscatine (2000) who demonstrated that healthy cnidarians expel actively dividing zooxanthellae cells in order to maintain a constant algal population density within the host.

Despite the inability to compare the numbers of Symbiodinium-like cells obtained from different coral hosts as mentioned in the results Section 3.2, it is clear that certain corals always show a high presence of Symbiodinium-like cells in their tissue and mucus. C. microphthalma was found to harbor the highest number of Symbiodinium in both tissue and mucus samples in all inshore reef systems and in Qaro Island and must be characterized by the production of specific chemical attractants favoured by Symbiodinium, a point that is worthy of further investigation. It is well known that different corals produce chemical compounds that attract dinoflagellates, which aggregate near certain corals while they fail to do so with others (Pasternak et al., 2006).

div.head: The diversity of Symbiodinium associated with Kuwait corals
div.p: The corals tested in the current study are all zooxanthellated species. Amplification of different genetic regions, i.e., 18S rRNA, 28S rRNA and ITS, facilitates testing for the presence of different Symbiodinium types in coral mucus and tissue. Except for P. daedalea, all tested corals harbored Symbiodinium clade C alone in the tissue and mucus. Phylogenetic analysis (Fig. 2) provides evidence that clade C dominated the clone library. At least 4 subclades could be recognized, and the majority clustered close to C2 type Symbiodinium. This is similar to the findings of Hume et al. (2013) that showed the presence of C3 and C15 members in F. pallida, C3 and C36 in P. daedalea and C3 and C21 in A. clathrata sampled from Abu Dhabi. Symbiodinium clade C is widely distributed in nature (Pochon et al., 2004) and includes many thermotolerant subclades, such as subclade C15, which predominated in warm habitat corals (LaJeunesse et al., 2003;Van Oppen et al., 2005;Fabricius et al., 2004). On the other hand, non-thermotolerant clade C members were also found in association with corals that survive in warm environments due to the hosts' ability to modify the mechanism of thermotolerance among the holobionts. This may explain why Acropora tenuis associated with the non-thermotolerant subclade C1 is more thermotolerant than the Acropora millepora associated with the thermotolerant Symbiodinium clade D (Fabricius et al., 2004).

The predominance of Symbiodinium clade C in Kuwaiti corals emphasizes the importance of this clade and supports the findings of Hume et al. (2013), who reported the presence of clade C3 Symbiodinium in nine coral species sampled from Abu Dhabi waters. However, it contradicts the findings of Baker et al. (2004), Mostafavi et al. (2007) and Shahhosseiny et al. (2011), which indicate the dominance of clade D in the south and north of the Arabian Gulf. Clade D was described as resistant to thermal stress (Brown et al., 2002;Thornhill et al., 2006) and common on reefs routinely exposed to high temperatures (Baker et al., 2008). The current study showed the presence of clade D only in seawater samples, but none of the tested coral tissue or mucus was found to harbor clade D. This observation supports the findings of Hume et al. (2013) who reported the absence of clade D from 7 coral species sampled from Abu Dhabi during the summer. They concluded that clade D did not proliferate under the extreme conditions that occur south of the Arabian Gulf. However, the presence of clade D in the water may indicate the importance of this clade to other marine invertebrates such as sea anemones and sponges. It may also reflect that in a thermally variable environment such as the Kuwait marine system, clade C may have a stronger role in stabilizing corals than clade D. P. daedalea was the only coral in the current study that harbored clades A, B and C in its tissue. Spring and autumn samples contained clades A, B, and C, while summer samples contained clades B and C. Corals in Kuwaiti seawater are known to bleach during the winter, when the seawater temperature drops dramatically below the optimum temperature at which the coral can grow. The coral flourish again in the spring and reach their optimum activity during the summer; hence the coral spawning season in Kuwait extends from May until August every year (Carpenter et al., 1997). Therefore, the detection of clade A in coral tissue in the spring fits within the explanation provided by Douglas (2003) that Symbiodinium clade A is predominant in coral after bleaching, suggesting an adaptation of the coral for bleaching by a shift in the Symbiodinium community, in which it is expected that the physiology of the holobionts is stabilized under different environmental conditions (Burnett, 2002). However, the reason that clade B was predominant in P. daedalea tissue sampled in the summer is vague, especially given that clade B is temperature-sensitive and photosynthetically insignificant and produces a low quality photosynthate in comparison with other Symbiodinium genotypes (Venn et al., 2008). Therefore, the reason why P. daedalea retains this symbiont during the high temperature season cannot be explained, especially because none of the other tested corals was found to harbor this symbiont. However, Jones et al. (2008) reported that certain coral species revert to their thermally sensitive symbionts after recovery from bleaching. This is the first study to suggest the presence of clade B in Gulf corals using the RFLP and DGGE techniques; however, the prepared clone library failed to detect this type of Symbiodinium, but this could be attributed to the low number of clones processed.

In addition to the temporal variation in the Symbiodinium communities associated with Umm Al-Maradim P. daedalea, a spatial variation was evident when the data collected from Qita'at Benaya on April was included in the analysis. P. daedalea tissue sampled in April 2008 from Qit'at Benaya was found to harbor Symbiodinium clades B and C, while Umm Al-Maradim samples contained three genotypes, clades A, B and C. The results can be considered as a demonstration of the concept of an "ecospecies" (Buddemeier et al., 2004) in which a single coral species can be associated with different clade(s), as determined by the surrounding environment, to ensure the optimum physiological activity of the coral. However, Platygyra dadaela was the only coral that was shown to harbor clades A, B and C in our study and was also the only coral that was severely affected by a recent bleaching incident that took place in Kuwait in September 2015 (Anon, 2015). Reports from inshore and offshore reef systems in Kuwait showed that P. dadaela suffered 100% damage (Fig. S3, Supplementary data) while the other coral species reported ranges between to 97%.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Kuwait corals harbor high numbers of Symbiodinium in their tissue and mucus that were found to be mostly affiliated with clade C. Symbiodinium clade C was detected in Kuwait corals throughout the warm and cold seasons, which may reflect the potential role of this type of Symbiodinium to help corals tolerate the great variations in water temperature that characterize the northern Arabian Gulf.

figure.figDesc: The total number of free-living Symbiodinium-like cells sampled from 3 inshore and 3 offshore reef systems in the period between April-October 2008.

figure.figDesc: The total number of Symbiodinium-like cells in four coral hosts (A) tissue and (B) mucus sampled from Qit'at Benaya reef system on May 2008.

figure.head: Fig. 6 .
figure.figDesc: The total number of Symbiodinium-like cells in P. daedalea tissue and mucus sampled from Qit'at Benaya and Umm Al-Maradim reef systems on April 2008.

figure.head: Fig. 7 .
figure.figDesc: Total number of Symbiodinium-like cells in P. daedalea tissue and mucus sampled from Umm Al-Maradim coral reef system at three different seasons (i.e. April, July and October 2008).

figure.head: Fig. 8 .
figure.figDesc: Principle component analysis showing the correlation between five seawater parameters (i.e. pH, temperature, conductivity, salinity and turbidity) and the total number of Symbiodinium-like cells in coral tissue, mucus and free-living Symbiodinium-like cells found in water (water).

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: We are grateful to Mr. Abdullah Al-Kanderi and Mr. Raid AL-Kanderi for their help in the fieldwork. Additionally, we would like to acknowledge the general facility project number (GS01/02) for ABI 3130xI Genetic Analyzer service provided by the Biotechnology Center, Faculty of Science. This study was financially sponsored by the Research Administration, Kuwait University under project number (YS01/08).
